stem: The nurse is reviewing the pediatric immunization schedule with a parent. Match each age group with the vaccines typically recommended during that visit.

columns.text: DTaP, RV, Hib, IPV, PCV13, HepB (except at 4 mo)

rationale.correct: Timing of vaccines maximizes immunity and minimizes vulnerability. (r1) HepB is the only vaccine given at birth. (r2) Infancy visits (2, 4, 6 mo) cover the 'core' respiratory and GI pathogens. (r3) Living-virus vaccines (MMR, Varicella) are generally delayed until 1 year of age. (r4) Adolescence includes boosters (Tdap) and protection against STIs (HPV) and meningitis.
rationale.incorrect: MMR should not be given to an infant under 12 months unless in highly specific outbreak scenarios, due to maternal antibody interference.
clinicalPearls: Instruct parents that mild fever and soreness are normal; but high fever or crying for >3 hours (in infants) requires a call to the provider.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: You don't give the 'Lively' ones (MMR, Varicella) until they are 'One' year old.

reviewUnits.heading: CDC Immunization Schedule 2026
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must verify the child's records and screen for contraindications (e.g., egg allergy for certain flu shots, immunocompromised state for live vaccines).
reviewUnits.source: CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP)
